thread.title: In Transit: Hiking and Biking in Tasmania
thread.title_full: In Transit: Hiking and Biking in Tasmania

author: DIANE DANIEL
title: In Transit: Hiking and Biking in Tasmania
text: Hiking and Biking in Tasmania AUG. 29, 2015 See More » Guests will explore a number of Tasmania’s national parks (more than 35 percent of the island is national parkland); mountain ranges, including Cradle Mountain; and high-altitude lakes, like St. Clair and Dove. Wildlife viewing may include Tasmanian devils, platypuses, kangaroos, wallabies, koalas and wombats. Cultural stops include the 19th-century Port Arthur penal settlement, now an open-air museum; and the Museum of Old and New Art, built into the side of a cliff on the Moorilla Estate winery on Berriedale peninsula. The tour leaves from Port Arthur on Jan. 23 and costs $2,575 per person with double occupancy. A version of this article appears in print on August 30, 2015, on page TR3 of the New York edition .
